field_reports.description:
Since the beginning of 2025, wildfires in Portugal have burned an estimated 60,000 hectares across multiple districts, with 6,393 rural fire incidents recorded up to 11 August. Numerous large-scale events have led to preventive evacuations and significant damage to rural areas. The most affected regions have been in the North and Centre of the country, where mountainous and forested landscapes, combined with hot and dry weather, have created critical fire conditions.

The National Civil Protection issued Rural Fire Danger warnings on 17 and 27 June and 25 July, based on forecasts of hot and dry weather and an increased wildfire risk. A State of Alert was declared for the entire mainland from 3 to 7 August 2025, later extended to cover the period from 8 to 13 August 2025.

The Portuguese Red Cross has been actively engaged in the response, providing rest areas for firefighters, emergency transport and victim evacuation support, and logistical assistance in affected regions. The Red Cross has also activated a Crisis Room to coordinate its operations and responses effectively.

As of 12 August, the National Society has been present in 15 operational theatres since 27 July, deploying 222 operational staff and 29 logistical personnel, supported by 15 vehicles and 28 activated local branches. The Emergency Operations Center has been operating 24/7. As a preventive measure, logistical trailers (for setting up population support areas), a drone team, and a command and communications vehicle are on standby.

field_reports.description:
On the morning of April 28th, a widespread communications and power outage struck, leaving the affected communities without electricity or access to telecommunications.

The blackout disrupted critical infrastructure, including airports, causing significant transportation delays and cancellations. Hospitals and multiple medical facilities have been severely impacted, facing challenges in maintaining essential services due to the lack of power, activated contingency plans.

The loss of traffic control systems, such as traffic lights, are leading to numerous road accidents. Emergency services have been also hampered, as residents were unable to call emergency numbers 112 due to the failure of mobile and landline networks.

Several supermarkets were forced to close due to failures in payment systems and incidents of public panic, further complicating access to essential goods.

The SIRESP network — the Portuguese state's exclusive communications network for command, control, and coordination in emergencies — also suffered major disruptions, with all antenna towers experiencing power failures. Although 18 backup generators were mobilized preemptively, the system's central operations center (COR) has only five hours of energy autonomy remaining.

The cause of the blackout remains unknown. Meanwhile, the affected populations face mounting risks to public health, safety, emergency response capabilities, and access to basic services.


After 12 hours without power, some services are gradually being restored. Communications are being reestablished, although call lines remain unstable but are still reachable. Households are slowly regaining electricity.

field_reports.description:
To determine the scope and scale of this event, secondary information from national government bodies and their official assessments has been used, alongside data from the PRC's initial needs assessment through triangulation. It is important to note that this assessment is preliminary and does not reflect the full extent of the damage or impact. Ongoing assessments will provide additional information, and this report will be updated accordingly.
According to the National Emergency and Civil Protection Authority, more than 37,772 personnel have been involved in the response to the fire emergency, supported by 10,639 ground resources and over 827 aerial missions. The European Civil Protection Mechanism also deployed eight additional aircraft to assist firefighting efforts, which are working alongside local resources to contain the most severe outbreaks. International support has also included technical, financial, and material assistance.

Considering that the affected areas were declared to be in a state of calamity (the declaration of the government doesn't state a list of municipalities or districts), it is estimated that at least 10% of the total population in these councils had their daily lives impacted by the disaster. This corresponds to approximately 41,329 people in total. Additionally, as reported by ANEPC, five people have died as a result of the fires, and 161 people have been injured, 12 critically. In response to the tragic loss of life, the government declared 20 September a Day of National Mourning to honor the victims.

The initial needs assessment conducted by the PRC identifies that the main needs of the affected populations are related to accommodation, hygiene kits, drinking water, psychosocial support, food support and financial support. Furthermore, authorities reported that thousands were indirectly affected due to destroyed infrastructure, power outages, and road closures, which prevented access to workplaces.

The most vulnerable populations are in rural areas of Aveiro, Viseu, Coimbra, Braga, Porto and Castelo Branco, where the fires forced evacuations, destroyed homes, and disrupted livelihoods. The economic consequences are particularly severe in agriculture and forestry dependent areas, where decreased productivity is expected to increase economic vulnerability among affected families. Major road closures for at least two days further disrupted daily routines, with many residents unable to work and several companies forced to adjust or cancel services. Beyond material losses, the psychological toll is significant, with many requiring psychosocial support due to the trauma and imminent danger caused by the fires.

As of September 15, 2024, Portugal is grappling with significant wildfires, especially in the central and northern regions. The fires have been exacerbated by unusually high temperatures and dry conditions. Emergency services are actively working to contain the blazes, but the situation remains challenging due to the fires' intensity and rapid spread. The government has issued warnings and evacuation orders in the affected areas, and resources from neighboring countries are being mobilized to assist with firefighting efforts.

So far, there are 6 big wildfires in course. Firefighting efforts in Aveiro Region (Oliveira de Azeméis, Albergaria-a-Velha, and Sever do Vouga) have resulted in three fatalities, according to the National Authority for Emergency and Civil Protection. One person was found carbonized in the Sever do Vouga fire, another suffered a heart attack in the Albergaria-a-Velha fire, and a firefighter died during a lunch break in the field.

There have also been 18 reported injuries, as reported by civil protection authorities, with 6 being civil protection officers. Approximately 70 people have been evacuated, and at least five properties, including homes, have been affected by the flames. Additionally, about 20 houses have been destroyed. The fires, which began between Sunday and today, have impacted various rural areas in the North and Central regions.

The Portuguese Government has requested support from the European Civil Protection Mechanism (UCPM), leading to the deployment of eight aircraft to assist with firefighting.

 

The Portuguese Red Cross has deployed the following resources since September 15:

  • 1 Mental Health and Psychosocial Support (MHPSS) Officer in Crisis
  • 7 Liaison Officers at Command Posts
  • 4 Multiple Transport Vehicles for Supporting Evacuations
  • 46 Emergency Medical Technicians in 23 Basic Life Support Ambulances
  • 1 Mobile Medical Post to upgrade an active Health Center with Advanced Life Support
  • 2 Command and Communication Vehicles
  • Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) National Disaster Response Team activated for wildfire monitoring
  • 1 Temporary Emergency Shelter with 15 beds
  • A total of 80 staff/volunteers

Data from field interventions is still being collected.

The Disaster Management Department has still pre-positioned 500 hygiene kits and emergency shelter supplies for 500 people.

The situation is expected to worsen during the night due to high-intensity winds and new fire projections.

 

Updated at 9pm 16th September

field_reports.description:
On the 14th July, all mainland is in Red Allert. Because of major fires, many people have been temporarily evacuated from their homes and a few houses and warehouses have been completely damaged. 

Accordingly to the National Civil Protection Authority, the exceptional Heat Wave is active until 17th of July, being less severe from 15th July 2022. On 14th July are expected favorable meteorological conditions for the progression of fires. 

Both National Authorities and Portuguese Red Cross have equipment and staff/volunteers on prevention until 17th July, additionally to those already in field.

Alert Status for a Heat Wave between July 8th 2022 and July 15th 2022, for the entire mainland:

The National Operational Coordination Center of the National Emergency and Civil Protection Authority, according to the forecast by the Portuguese Institute of the Sea and the Atmosphere, regarding the increased risk of rural fires for the next few days, with most of mainland territory at High, Very High or Maximum levels of heat, determined the Special Alert Status of the Integrated Protection and Relief Operations System, for the Special Rural Fire Fighting System, in all districts of the mainland.

field_reports.summary: PRT: Volcanic Eruption - 2022-04 - Azores - Earthquake-Volcanic Crisis
field_reports.description:
On March 19th, an earthquake measuring 2.9 on the Richter Scale was felt on the island of São Jorge, in the Azores. Since then, seismic activity on the island has registered a significant increase and remains above reference values. Since the beginning of the crisis, there have been more than 20.000 earthquake of which 215 were noticed by population.

On March 23rd, the Azores Regional Government increased the Volcanic Alert Level to V4 (danger on volcanic cone, caldera and all island, possibility of very large eruption and also chance of flank eruption / hazardous eruption is possible within days).

A 3.8-magnitude (Richter Scale) tremor struck 2 kilometers south from Velas in Ocean last March 29th

The total number or tremors have been reducing last days, but specialists say the risk analyses hasn´t changed.

This fissure system, which coincides with the main volcanic cones of the island, is still active and has now recorded a release of energy that is unusual in recent years.

results.name: PRT: Volcanic Eruption - 2022-04 - Azores - Earthquake-Volcanic Crisis
